comments.author: MissLindchen99

comments.text:
+Chris Ayers Well, actually I thinks its more "lust" than "love". The guy 
sings about being addicted to love, but its ironic because he he treats the 
girls with love for their bodies. Not for who they are.
SPOILERS ALERT
Even at the end of the movie, when he is getting arrested by the cops, he 
tells the cops that he takes care them, but really he doesn't. He does not 
"love" them, and that's obvious since he is making money off of there 
bodies and also not to mention, kills two of his own women(Amber & Blondie) 
when he feels betrayed by them. If you love someone, you will not try to 
sell their bodies to anyone. And if you love someone, you will not kill 
them because they have betrayed/hurt you or were simply just trying to 
leave you. And if someone tries to leave you, its obvious you're doing 
something wrong.

comments.text:
Hmmm... Isn't this movie an exploration of a schizophrenic's mind - where 
the actual heroine (can't remember her name) projects a different reality 
through Baby Doll (a character of her own making, or her alternate self)?

That's how I understood the ending, when the character was given a 
lobotomy, and in her alternate reality, she is staging her escape with Baby 
Doll's help. I could be mistaken.

i thought it was pretty clever how they told a story (which is s sensitive 
subject for some I assume) and just replaced it and put it in a different 
setting that still conveys what is going on without having to show a dingy 
asylum or a typical plot but, portrays it how the main character sees it. 
Its something that was similarly done in the Life of Pi much later on and 
its something I find very interesting and wish more films would do﻿

comments.author: AcidicCritic

comments.text:
Sucker Punch operates on three levels: first a reality, then a sub-reality 
where the psych ward is a strange brothel, and finally a level consisting 
of a dream world where action sequences outside of time and space occur . 
Zack Snyder said the film is a critique of sexism in geek culture and 
conversion of women into mere objects
comments.author: Kenia Odett

comments.text:
From Dictionary.com Sucker Punch: 
verb (used with object), Slang.
1. to strike (someone) with an unexpected blow.

This was clearly the whole point. Zack Snyder laid down some b.s. to create 
a fantasy about "empowerment" by having women in with a bogus asylum 
storyline, to link a bunch of random action sequences with some T&A to 
strictly appeal to 18-30 males. The true suckers were people who went to 
see this movie in the theatres and paid the bucks to watch it. The people 
who think they "get it", are the the ones that just bought into a marketing 
line that the movie is deeper than it is. ﻿
comments.author: leftcoaster67

comments.text:
Sucker Punch is one of those movies that you either "get it" or you don't 
get it.﻿

comments.text:
+Peter Iasillo, Jr. No. Thats just the justification people use to explain 
why everyone hates it. We get it. We get that Baby Doll is not the "star of 
the show" Sweet Pea is. We get that its not reality, but what she imagines 
because she is getting a lobotomy. That Sweet Pea is the real her escaping, 
and Baby Doll is the body, all that is left behind…. Its still a shit 
movie. Its still about women dressed in infantilizing sex outfits, using 
their sexuality to manipulate men who have power over them, and that 
appeals to men. Thats all it really is.

comments.author: Ronnie Skeptz

comments.text:
+Ronnie Skeptz I've given up trying to understand this shit. If I want to 
hear an inspiring spiel on female sexual liberation and patriarchal boys 
club politics, I'll listen to a feminist lecture.
But I won't get all that information from this trashy flick.
It's in what it does of being a violent, sexy niche kitsch flick catering 
to a predominately male audience. That's it.
Romanticize and lift it up all you want, just cause you slap wings on a pig 
don't make it a fairy.
comments.author: Ryan James

comments.text:
+Ryan James i disagree, i think you (as many people did) developed a point 
of view that just stops at "sexualization". I actually think this movie 
criticises a society in which many women still think they need to sexualize 
themselves to get what they want, and teaches that everyone is strong 
enough and has "all the weapons they need" to get their freedom and reach 
their goals, whatever they are, not only by sexualizing themselves but by 
fighting, risking everything for something they believe in. This movie is 
is not a masterpiece in my opinion, but you can't say it's sexist
comments.author: Ronnie Skeptz

comments.author: mauricio garcia

comments.text:
+strikeclone
It's ridiculous that you can fabricate your conjectural and false 
accusations against me just based on the term feminazism which I have no 
idea exactly what it means let alone being a part of.
You have read way too much into my first comment. Chill out! Your talking 
about the innocence of this movie being taken away by my first comment of 
hoping Baby Doll had been successful in her escape attempt and be able to 
get vengence against male dominated evil is just ludicrous.
comments.author: simon6071

comments.text:
+simon6071 ~I~ don't think the movie has an ideological message, in fact I 
said the exact opposite, I think it's you who have the ideological motives 
here and hence why I said what I said.

And in the real world there is plenty of female dominated evil which was 
also part of my point.

There are three possible reasons why you "present your prejudice with a 
pretentious display of convoluted language";

A. Didn't even bother to read what I said in its entirety.

B. Did read it but completely failed to grasp my meaning.

C. Did read it, did grasp my full meaning, realised it somehow disagreed 
the patriarchy, rape culture, etc etc that is the cherished fantasy of 
feminazism and in the true spirit of that debased ideology you now must 
attempt to obfuscate, distort, and blatantly lie in order to discredit and 
silence any and all opposition regardless of the facts.

Clearly it's C and as such I am not going to try to reason with you and 
pick your accusations and fallacious statements apart with mere facts as 
you cannot reason with feminazi's nor their mangina allies.

I hope and think that anyone capable of critical thinking will understand 
what I am saying in my previous reply and its not mitigated one little bit 
by your several attempts to reduce this to a personal battle of insults.

Moreover your personal attacks only lessen any point you ~may~ of had 
because the fact you have to attempt to score points against me personally 
only shows you have no interested in ~making~ a point. 

I am not sorry that you find my use of the English language to make my 
points offensive, I am not sorry that I can articulate my arguments without 
resorting to pathetic attempts at personal insults and attacks.

P.S. one minor thing I have to point out, the "nazi zombies" are in fact 
German zombies in a trench system over which biplanes and zeppelins are 
fighting. Clearly this is a scene based on world war one campaigns, 
1914-1918 which gave us the Versi treaty which is often held up as a 
prominent cause of the disaffection of the German people which Hitler and 
his Nazi party exploited in the years running up to the second world war.

Just another indication of a lack of basic understanding evident in your 
reply.
comments.author: strikeclone

comments.text:
+strikeclone
This is a movie about a girl who uses fantasy to fight back male dominated 
evil. Yes, there is such a thing called male dominated evil. It's not the 
concoction of feminists.
If dressing sexy is what it takes for girls to get the message across, so 
be it.
Femininazism? Those girls were fight Nazi zombies in the movie, weren't 
they? I love it. Wonder how femininazism and misogyny could come in play in 
the situation.
You think holding the view that there is a problem of male dominated evil 
in this world is a form of extremism?
Thank you for telling me about your extremism.
It's only your prejudiced view that Sucker Punch the movie was only meant 
to be for pure entertainment and employment with no food for thought.
I don't think this movie has anything to do with politics, neither has my 
comment for this movie. That you somehow think just because a movie has 
hidden ideological message then it would lose its innocence is just 
ignorant.
You are quite successful in convincing me that you are very talented in 
presenting your prejudice with a pretentious display of convoluting 
language.
comments.author: simon6071

comments.text:
+simon6071 Its not "male dominated evil" its just plain old evil, men and 
women are involved in it in the film as they are in real life.

Its ironic to me that when female characters like those portrayed in Sucker 
Puncher are the "under dogs" fighting against presumed "male dominated 
evil" that its OK for them to be dressed up as school girls, in hot pants, 
boob tubes, mini skirts, leotards, fishnet tights etc etc and this makes 
them ~plucky~ and have "fighting spirit" but if a similarly attired 
character is portrayed in a film or video game where she happens to be just 
a random bystander in the story or anything but the lead heroine that this 
suddenly transmutes through the power of femininazism into misogyny. 

I put it to you that extremism comes in many forms and will alter, twist 
and obscure the truth of anything in order to promote its own debased 
ideology and/or denigrate opponents of its debased ideology.

Some, arguable most, further arguably all stories and films are no more 
than they appear and should be taken at face value as entertainment for us 
and employment for the cast with all due benefit of the doubt. To be left 
alone by all political and ideological commentators who seek to exploit 
that which is innocent in order to promoted their particular (twisted) 
world view.
comments.author: strikeclone

comments.text:
I like how splendid this movie was made and the fighting spirit it carries 
against male dominated evil. However, I don't like the ending because I 
want to see Baby Doll successfully escaped as well and gave his evil step 
father what he deserved. We have seen too many big villains escape 
punishment in reality, so we want to see them punished at least in the 
fantasy world. Letting a major villain go unpunished is the biggest let 
down of this movie.
comments.author: simon6071
